description: Demolition of existing garage and petrol filling station and erection of new four storey building above basement, comprising 9 no. self-contained apartments with associated car parking and landscaping.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the windows shown as serving bathrooms at first and second floor levels in the north-eastern (rear) elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or roof lights at first floor level or above in the north-western (flank) or south-eastern (flank) elevations shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development to which this permission relates, a strategy to deal with the potential risks associated with any contamination of the site shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. This strategy shall include the following components:(i) A preliminary risk assessment which has identified: all previous uses; potential contaminants associated with those uses; a conceptual model of the site indicating sources, pathways and receptors; and potentially unacceptable risks arising from contamination at the site.(ii) A site investigation scheme (based on 7(i) above) to provide information for a detailed assessment of the risk to all receptors that may be affected, including those off site.(iii) The results of the site investigation and the detailed risk assessment referred to in (ii) and, based on this, an options appraisal and remediation strategy giving full details of the remediation measures required and how they are to be undertaken.(iv) A verification plan providing details of the data that will be collected in order to demonstrate that the works set out in the remediation strategy in (iii) are complete and identifying any requirements for longer-term monitoring of pollutant linkages, maintenance and arrangements for contingency action.Any changes to these components will require the written consent of the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented in full.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. These details are required prior to commencement of development in the interests of health and safety.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a verification report demonstrating the completion of works set out in the approved remediation strategy and the effectiveness of the remediation shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The report shall include results of sampling and monitoring carried out in accordance with the approved verification plan to demonstrate that the site remediation criteria have been met.Reason: To ensure that the site does not pose any further risk to human health or the water environment by demonstrating that the requirements of the approved verification plan have been met and that remediation of the site is complete, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

If, during development, contamination not previously identified is found to be present at the site then no further development (unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority) shall be carried out until a remediation strategy detailing how this contamination will be dealt with has been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The remediation strategy shall be implemented as approved.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution from previously unidentified contamination sources at the development site, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No drainage systems involving the infiltration of surface water into the ground shall be implemented on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution from mobilised contaminants, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No piling or other foundation designs involving penetrative methods shall be implemented on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority. If such methods are proposed, a risk assessment, demonstrating that there would be no resultant unacceptable risk to groundwater shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The proposed development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution from mobilised contaminants, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development shall be carried out in accordance with Water Efficiency Calculator for New Dwellings dated 23 June 2020 unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a scheme to enhance the nature conservation interest of the site shall be submitted to and agreed in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall then be implemented in full prior to beneficial occupation of the development.Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with policy 7.19 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a car park management plan (detailing how spaces will be allocated, how the use of the car park will be controlled, the signage necessary to direct pedestrians and vehicles) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved plan.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the vehicular crossover(s) as shown on the approved plans shall be provided (including reinstating the footway to the satisfaction of the local planning authority) and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure proper vehicular access to the site in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any redundant accesses to the site shall be stopped up and the footway reinstated to the satisfaction of the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure proper vehicular access to the site in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used)xx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided in each direction where the access meets the back edge of footway and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: In the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, one car parking space shall be provided with active provision for electric vehicle charging points and one further space shall be provided with passive charging points and thereafter permanently retained.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sustainable drainage strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan for surface water drainage at the site using SuDS methods shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved sustainable drainage strategy prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, privacy screening, 1.7m in height as measured from the floor level adjacent to the screen, shall be erected along the northern and southern edges of the balconies and/or terraces. Aside from essential fixings, the screen(s) shall be constructed entirely of obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with Energy Strategy dated 23/06/20 unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The applicant proposes a first-floor side extension that would have a set down from the ridge of the roof by approximately 150mm, set back from the front of the dwelling by approximately 450mm and would not have a set in from the boundary facing the highway by at least 1m. Officers acknowledge that this would not respect the guidelines of the Residential Design SPD. The proposed first-floor extension would appear disproportionate, not subordinate to the existing dwellinghouse and would be highly prominent within the street scene due to the corner plot location and position forward of the established building line along Station Road. The proposed ground floor rear extension would have a depth of approximately 3.5m and a total flat roof height of approximately 2.7m. Whilst officers acknowledge that the flat roof would not respect the pitched roof form of the host dwelling, it is considered that the proposal would, in isolation, appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host building.In regards to the proposed change of material from brick to render and the roof to grey slate, officers consider it would not significantly affect the character and appearance in the wider area, as it would not be incongruous in the vicinity of Station Road. However, it would adversely impact the symmetry shared with adjoining neighbouring property, as No. 12 Station Road has a brick finish.Overall, officers consider that there would be adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and would not be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Report which suitably addresses the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.)In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi-detached building.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. ProposalPlanning permission is sought for the conversion of garage into habitable space and erection of single storey side extension. Changes to ground floor fenestrations.Consultation 6no. properties were notified of the proposal. No representation received.Planning History23/00431/HOU - Conversion of garage into habitable space and erection of single storey side/rear extension. Granted planning permission, dated 28.03.2023.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers;- Impact upon Highways; and- Fire Safety Character and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposals seek to convert the integral garage into a habitable space (bedroom with en-suite) with associated change from existing garage door to a window of a similar appearance to the existing main windows within the front elevation of the property. This is considered to be an acceptable alteration which would not result in any harm to the overall character and appearance of the host dwelling. The proposed single-storey side extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained behind the existing built form. The proposals involve the erection of a modest side extension to the rear of the existing garage to the same width as the garage and to a depth to join the existing rear building line of the dwellinghouse. The extension would have a part flat, part pitched roof form. The proposed extension is considered minor in its scale and appropriate in its design, in keeping with the host building. Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The conversion of the garage, proposed side extension and alterations to the fenestration would not cause any materially harmful impacts to neighbouring amenity.Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Impact upon HighwaysPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The application involves the conversion of the integral garage space. The garage is not capable of fitting a modern car. The area of hardstanding/driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used for car parking.As such, the conversion would not result in the loss of a space that would impact upon highway safety.Fire Safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.ConclusionThe proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.

Condition 3 (Facing Materials) of planning permission 23/00180/FUL states:Notwithstanding the submitted information, prior to any above ground development (excluding demolition) details of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Officer response: The submitted details in relation to condition 3 (facing materials) are considered to be sufficient. As such, these details are hereby approved.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of a hip to gable and rear a dormer roof extension together with 2 additional roof lights on the main front roof and one roof light of the flat roof at the rear above the staircase.Consultations10 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: It is acknowledged that the proposed rear dormer roof extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 39 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended set in distances, however considering the proposed bulk and mass of the extension and the proposed design, it is considered to appear in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. It is noted that the property benefits from permitted development rights with regards to roof extensions and therefore it can be considered as a 'fallback' position in respect of the mass and bulk and siting of the proposed roof extensions. The proposed rear dormer would not be directly visible within the street view, as such it would not result in significant impact on the existing street scene. The proposed front roof lights and hip to gable roof extension is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. The proposed materials (roof tiles and render) would be of similar appearance to the existing materials. As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Condition 4 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 23/01016/HOU states:Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details:1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point;2) Appropriate fire alarm systems;3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread;5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained. Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.Officers response: The submitted Fire Statement Rev June 2023  is considered to be sufficient. As such, details submitted in relation to condition 4 are hereby approved. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved strategy and thereafter maintained.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals; 1 supporting comment has been received and 2 objections have been received, relating to: - Excessive height or bulk of buildings - Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosur - Inappropriate design/layout - Privacy - Unacceptable or incompatible useThe concern raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.Relevant Planning History- 22/03459/HOU - Amendments to Planning Permission 22/01394/HOU (Conversion of garage into store, erection of two-storey side, part two-storey part single-storey rear and front porch extension) to allow changes in roof tiles, render colour, window frame colour and minor changes to front porch. - Granted 23 December 2022- 22/01394/HOU - Conversion of garage into store, erection of two storey side, part two storey part single storey rear and front porch extension - Granted 01 July 2022The key areas of assessment are: - The impact of the development on character and appearance. - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on highways. - The impact of the development on fire safety. This planning application seeks to obtain approval for a retrospective proposal; Conversion of garage into store, erection of two storey side, part two storey part single storey rear and front porch extension. Removal of front catslide. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The applicant previously submitted an application which slightly differs from the submitted proposal. The changes include the removal of the front cat-slide roof feature and the removal of the partial pitched roof to the single storey rear/side extension to a flat roof. The removal of the cat-slide roof would not usually be acceptable as they are a distinct feature found in Motspur Park. However, the removal of this feature would not cause significant harm to the character and appearance of the wider area as No.55 Motspur Park has also removed the cat-slide feature.The application partly proposes the construction of a two-storey side extension. The proposed two storey side extension would be set down from the ridge line of the existing dwelling house by approximately 0.7 metres, and set back sufficiently from the front elevation by approximately 1 metre. Additionally, this extension would not exceed 50% of the width of the original house. Officers note that this element would be set in from the boundary by approximately 0.8 metres. Whilst this aspect would not strictly meet the requirements of the Residential Design SPD 2013, which requires two-storey side extensions to be set in from the boundary by at least 1 metre to ensure a terracing effect does not occur, this would not warrant refusal alone as overall it would be a subordinate and proportionate addition. This element is therefore considered to have an acceptable impact in terms of character and appearance.The application also proposes the construction of a part two-storey rear extension. Whilst this element of the proposal would be of a significant scale, as it sited to the rear of the dwelling and would not be clearly visible from the streetscene, officers consider that it would not have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area. Regarding the construction of a porch area and alterations to an existing detached garage to the rear, officers consider these elements of the proposal to have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse.Finally the application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension with a flat roof. Whilst this extension would exceed the recommended depth and height for single storey rear extensions, it would appear proportionate to the the host dwelling.Officers acknowledge that the proposed changes to roof tiles, render colour, window frame colour and minor changes to front porch would not generally be features that are similar to the host dwelling or most dwelling in the vicinty of Motspur Park. However, the roof tile change from red/brown slate to grey slate and the proposed white render would not be incongruous as a few dwellings on Motspor Park do have grey tile. The existing white UPVC window frames into Dark Grey UPVC and the porch rearrangement would be different in the streetscene but is not considered to have any significant adverse impact.Therefore, on balance, officers consider that the proposed would still appear proportionate to the original dwellinghouse and would therefore have an acceptable impact on its character and appearance. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are No. 55 and No. 59 Motspur Park. In relation to No. 55 Motspur Park, the application proposes a number of windows on the side elevation of the main dwelling. In the event of an approval Officers consider that a condition to ensure that these windows are obscure glazed would be required, in the interest of protecting the privacy of neighbouring properties. Subject to the satisfaction of such a condition Officers consider that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the amenity of the neighbouring property at No. 55 Motspur Park in terms of loss of privacy. Similarly, Officers consider that the proposal would not have an unacceptable impact on the amenity of this neighbouring property through loss of sunlight or an overbearing appearance. In relation to No. 59 Motspur Park, the application proposes the installation of two windows on the side elevation of the detached garage. These windows would be at ground level and would face the neighbouring property at 59 Motspur Park. Officers consider that these windows are sited sufficiently far away from the boundary of this neighbouring property, and at a low enough level, for this element to not have a detrimental impact on the privacy of this neighbouring property. In relation to sunlight, an application at this site was previously refused as the applicant had failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed 1st floor rear extension would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on daylight/sunlight and the outlook of the closest habitable room windows at neighbouring property No. 59 Motspur Park. Due to the set in from the boundary of the proposed development, as well as the existence of an alleyway between these two properties (No.59 Motspur Park), and that the ground floor habitable room at this neighbouring property benefits from a number of windows, Officers consider that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable impact on the amenity of No. 59 Motspur Park by reason of loss of sunlight. Similarly, Officers do not consider the proposed would result in an overbearing impact.  HighwaysPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance.Officers Comments: The application proposes the conversion of an existing garage into a habitable room. To accommodate modern vehicles, proposed new garages should meet the required dimensions as recommended by Appendix 5 of the Sustainable Transport SPD, measuring 3 metres in width and 5.3 metres in depth internally. The existing garage would not meet the minimum required internal garage dimensions for one vehicle, and therefore the removal of this garage would not impact the parking provision on site. Furthermore, it is considered that the remaining hardstanding is of an adequate size to accommodate two off-street car parking spaces. Whilst this level of provision would be in excess of the maximum standards set out in the London Plan, this issue would not warrant a reason for refusal as it is reflective of the existing situation. Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3. Officers Comments: The proposal would result in a loss of access to the rear as well as the loss of a garage. Officers therefore consider it appropriate to attach a condition to the application in the event of an approval for the applicant to provide details of secure onsite cycle parking. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Statement which suitably addresses the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of a single storey rear extension.It is noted that this is an infill extension which will be the same depth as the existing partial single storey rear extension.Consultation11 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - Flood Risk; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to the existing situation between the neighbouring properties to either side of the development, no further harm has been identified. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The Flood Risk information supplied indicate a very low risk of surface flooding. Floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than the main dwelling. Floor levels will be subject to a condition should permission be granted. overall, the proposed development is considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.ProposalErection of two-storey side extension, alterations to front and rear fenestrations, and internal alterationsThis application follows recently refused application 23/00792/HOU dated 19.05.2023 for the erection of two-storey side extension, alterations to front and rear fenestrations, and internal alterations. This application was refused for the following reason;1) Due to its excessive depth and height along the shared boundary, the proposed extension would result in an unacceptable sense of enclosure and overbearing impact to No. 3 Lord Chancellor Walk, thereby conflicting with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012 and the Residential Design SPD, 2013.This reason for refusal would need to be addressed in order for this application to be successful.ConsultationSix neighbouring properties have been notified and one objection has been received stating:- shadows shown for winter equinox are incorrect.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.The Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character is a non-designated heritage asset.Paragraph 203 of the NPPF states that:The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer Comment: From a character and design perspective, the proposed development it is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is also considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and therefore, no adverse impacts on Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: With regards to neighbouring amenity, Officers note that the proposed height of the extension has been decreased from 7.5m to 6m. However, The proposed two storey side extension would still be deep with a depth of approximately 12.5m in very close proximity to the shared boundary with No. 3 Lord Chancellor Walk. It would be set in 1m from the boundary at to begin with but this separation decreases along the length of the boundary.Due to the excessive height in close proximity to the shared boundary with No. 3, and considering that the extension would project beyond the rear elevation of No. 3 by approximately 13m, officers still consider that the proposed extension would be overbearing and unneighbourly in relation to No. 3 Lord Chancellor Walk, and would result in an undue sense of enclosure. Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing impact/ sense of enclosure.Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments: While no Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021), Officers consider that the proposal should be able to meet the requirements of Policy D12(A). Were the application otherwise acceptable, a Fire Strategy would be secured by way of a planning condition. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

23/01419/FULApplication SiteThe site relates to the Kingston University Penrhyn Road campus, which comprises a range of buildings across the site.The Grove Crescent Conservation Area lies to the north and east  of the site. There  are various listed and locally listed Buildings in the vicinity.There are numerous trees on the site covered byTree Preservation Order.The site is within Flood Zone 1 (Low risk)The Site is within the Kingston Town Centre Action Area Plan boundary. The site has a Public Transport Accessibility Level of ranginging between 3 and 4 and is well served by public transport.ProposalThe proposed alterations are to the main entrance on the western facade fronting Penrhyn Road. There are two main elements:(i) Remodelling of the main Penrhyn Road entrance door to provide a new entrance with revolving door and canopy, signage and associated development; (ii) the erection of a new passenger lift within an internal courtyard (with lift overrun) immediately off the Penrhyn Road main entrance foyer ConsultationThe proposal was advertised by means of 4 site notices displayed at or near the site of proposed works. No comments have been received.GLAAS: the proposal is unlikely to have a significant effect on heritage assets of archaeological interest.The planning application is not in an Archaeological Priority Area. No further assessment or conditions are therefore necessary.  Tree Officer - original concerns about potential loss of trees addressed. As no loss of trees is proposed there is no objection to the proposal.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- Principle- The design of the proposed development; - Heritage- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. Principle of developmentCore Strategy Policy CS15 relates to the Future Needs of Kingston University and states that  The Council will continue to work in partnership with Kingston University recognising their importance in the local economy, to identify appropriate opportunities, including on their existing sites, to meet their needs for new and upgraded facilities and for smarter travel initiatives, including travel planning. Therefore, subject to compliance with other policies, the proposal would be supported in principle.DesignParagraph 124 of the NPPF states that the creation of high quality buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve. Good design is a key aspect of sustainable development, creates better places in which to live and work and helps to make development acceptable to communities. Paragraph 127 goes on to say that planning decisions should ensure that developments: will function well and add to the overall quality of the area; are visually attractive as a result of good architecture, layout and appropriate and effective landscaping; are sympathetic to local character and history; and establish a strong sense of place.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Officer Comment: The proposed entrance would be  in the form of a glazed curtain walling system that is gently recessed into the building, which it is advised has taken  inspiration from the original building design (prior to its remodelling in the 200's, which gives relief to the facade and allows the original columns to be expressed. A revolving door is proposed, and a slimline canopy above. The proposed works to the entrance to the Unversity  would help to  create a more legible entrance feature and an enhanced arrival experience. It is concluded that the alterations would enhance the appearance of the building.The lift would be concealed within the building as it is located within an internal courtyard. A  lift overrun  of  very modest scale (900 mm height) is set well back from the front facade and would not be prominent in views. The proposal is considered to be acceptable in terms of its detailed design and appearance. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Heritage Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                     Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer comment: The Grade II listed 1893 landmark building of County Hall lies to the north-west of the campus on Penrhyn Road. To the east of the campus on Grove Lane is the Grade II listed 1872 Church of St John. The Grove Crescent Conservation area lies to the north and east  of the campus buildings.The Main Building's entrance on the west façade is  located towards the southern end of the building and set back from the road frontage and therefore not readily visible from the Grove Crescent Conservation Area (GCCA). The entrance  lies to the south and west of the Grade II* listed County Hall building   and is not within the immediate setting of the listed building. The proposed external lift will be screened on all sides by the Main Building and Clattern Lecture Theatre which surround the courtyard. The overrun protrudes marginally above the building line and as noted above, due to the set back would not readily visible from surrounding streets. Overall, it is concluded that the proposal would not result in any material harm to the setting of heritage assets. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicies at a national, regional, and local level direct that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Due to  the nature of the works, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, noise or disturbance orloss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Policy D12 of The London Plan states: a)   In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all     development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure   that they: 1) Identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space: a) For fire appliances to be positioned on. b) Appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point. 2) Are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures. 3) Are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread. 4) Provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users.5) Develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in. 6) Provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Statement prepared by Osborn Associates.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). The lift will also be allocated as an evacuation lift as per the requirements of London Plan Policy D5.Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. TreesPolicy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy states that the Council will expect new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders are not adversely affected. Where trees are to be lost through development the Council will normally require the planting of two specimens for each tree lost.Whilst the submitted drawings are unclear, the applicant has confirmed that proposal does not involve the removal of any trees or changes. On this basis, this is acceptable and secured by condition.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance  with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling which has been in use as two separate flats since circa 1985.ProposalErection of single storey rear extension and changes to side fenestration of the ground floor flat.Consultation12 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- Standard of Accommodation;- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. Standard of AccommodationPolicies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy advise that proposals should relate well to their surroundings and be of a high standard of design to achieve a more attractive, sustainable and accessible environment.Officer Comment: The proposed rear extension would result in the loss of the majority of the current amenity space provided for the ground floor flat. This area can been seen as a separate fenced off area within the site photos.  However, the submitted existing and proposed drawings do not show the separate amenity spaces or how they would be affected by the proposed development.On the basis of the submitted information, it is considered that the proposals would result in a significant loss of  private amenity space for the ground floor flat which would detract from the standard of accommodation. It is considered that the overall standard of accommodation would bepoor and, for this reason, the proposal is contrary to Policy D6 of the London Plan 2021, Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Council's Residential Design SPD (2013). DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed extension, in isolation, is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The principal property to be considered with regards to neighbouring amenity is No. 27a Westbury Road. Officers note the presence of the existing rear extension hard up against the boundary with No. 27 the proposed extnsion in width would not further harm the current situation. It is considered therefore, that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

SuDS are proposed in the form of an underground cellular attenuation tank, providing a storage volume of 24 m3 has been proposed to contribute to the sustainable drainage of the site. However, it is not clear the discharge rate of the drainage system being proposed nor if the storage volume provided is sufficient to ensure that the drainage system does not flood in a 1 in 30 year rainfall event. The applicant should confirm the discharge rates being proposed. Also, drainage calculations are required to support the currently proposed drainage strategy.The applicant should provide calculations to demonstrate that the proposed drainage system can contain up to the 1 in 30 storm event without flooding and that any onsite flooding between the 1 in 30 and the 1 in 100 plus 40% climate change storm event should be safely contained on site. These calculations must include details of critical storm durations and demonstrate how the proposed system as a whole will function during different storm events.If any flooding occurs for the 1 in 100 year plus 40% climate change event, then details of where this flooding will occur and the volume of the flooding are required to demonstrate the site will remain safe.Also, a maintenance schedule for the surface water drainage system needs to be provided to include the maintenance tasks and frequency of the proposed drainage components. Also, a maintenance owner should be confirmed at this stage.
